results.title: Seven up
results.creator_credit: Paul Almond, Michael Apted and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “World in action”.
Life viewed by Britain’s seven year olds. They give their views on life, leisure, love, marriage, colour prejudice, education, money and their ambitions for the future.

results.title: 7 plus seven
results.creator_credit: Michael Apted and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World in action”.
Fourteen children from a variety of school backgrounds, interviewed in 1964 for television about their hopes and aspirations, are followed up seven years later. Extracts from the first program, made when the children were seven years old, are shown and the children comment on any changes in their ideas.

results.title: 42 Up
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “World in action”.
In 1964 a team from Granada Television set out to test the following theory - are children’s lives already mapped out for them by the age of seven? This was the start of a remarkable series which documents groups of children from childhood through puberty to adulthood. Of the original 14 subjects, 11 remain. Now halfway through their lives, how close are they to realising their dreams and ambitions? This enthralling film also starts asking grander questions common to all humans - what is love, what is character, what is success?

results.title: 35 up
results.creator_credit: Michael Apted and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World in action”.
The fifth in a series of remarkable documentaries which explore the lives of a diverse group of people who come before the cameras every seven years to be interviewed. Approaching middle-age the adults in this film are now settled in their lives, not completely fulfilled, but no longer so confident in the possibility of dreams coming true. Born into different social classes and different kinds of families, the adults in “35 Up” are candid about their experiences of divorce, having children, failure and death. The power of this film is that as we watch the children grow into adults we are made to ask ourselves challenging questions about the nature of family, community, heredity, class and human will. The success of the documentary has been such that it is now much imitated by film-makers across the globe.

results.title: 28 up
results.creator_credit: Michael Apted and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World in action”.
Fourteen children from a variety of school backgrounds, interviewed in 1964 for television about their hopes and aspirations, are followed up twenty-one years later. Extracts from the interviews made when the children were seven, fourteen, twenty-one and twenty-eight years old are shown. Those involved, comment on any changes in their ideas. This film is suitable for years 11-12 and tertiary level.

results.title: 21 Up
results.creator_credit: Margaret Bottomley, Michael Apted and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “World in action”.
In 1964, a number of seven year olds expressed their views on life, leisure, love, marriage, colour prejudice, education and money (SEVEN UP). Another program was made about them and their changing attitudes when they were fourteen (7 PLUS SEVEN). Now at twenty-one, using clips from these films, the program compares the responses of this group of individuals as they grow to adulthood. This film is recommended for Years 11-12 and Tertiary level education.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Margaret Bottomley, Michael Apted and Granada Television International
